TLDR; You're an absolute idiot.

First of all, developed countries DO NOT need more people. According to the 
Human Development Index 14.6% of the worlds population live in DEVELOPED 
countries, which still have higher relative growth and better standard of 
living compared to developing nations. On the other hand, there's a booming 
population in developing countries who face uneven development, 
deteriorating quality of life, and increased poverty. Why on Earth would we 
need more people in developed countries when there's BILLIONS in developing 
countries living in the poorest conditions. Why don't we focus on bringing 
them to a developed stage?

countries need MORE people (quantity), now you're saying we need quality.

over, since this is based on prolonging life expectancy) has more potential 
and capabilities to offer society than a new born child. What are they 
going to do? When diseases such as Alzheimer's and dementia set in they'll

society that and older person would not be able to achieve.

problem', well you certainly are special. Food and resources are LIMITED on

similarity index, the closest planet to that of Earth (Kepler-186f) is 500

comments.text:
+Justin Johnson This is all about the static brain (artificial) and the 
plastic brain (the organic brain that everyone already has) resulting in a 
symbiotic brain. The static brain will be most likely made up of chips with 
biofilm coatings to prevent infections once placed inside the brain...the 
locations where the connections are made I refer to as anchor points...and 
it looks like you can't just shove pieces of hardware into living brain 
tissue so perhaps on top of the brain cortical regions (ie. the 'utah 
array' that can control devices,limbs via the motor cortex) and of course 
these devices will get smaller and smaller and can be powered wirelessly or 
even use the body's own thermal-heat to power it (a more greener energy 
solution). The hardest obstacle to overcome is not the memory because for 
instance all it would be needed to save a person is to preserve their past 
24h existence/experiences and would not even have to include "highlights" 
of their lives...they would simply continue on making new memories as if 
nothing would of happened...albeit it would feel kinda strange...perhaps 
some sort of experiment needs to be done here in order to determine how 
much memory loss it would take for an average individual to loose 
their...what can be described as their core self and identity. The hardest 
brain regions to make the connection to the 'static' brain will be the 
thinking/future planning portions because these are connected with all 
other regions of the brain such as planning areas with memory areas. In 
fact the entire brain let's say from the frontal regions 'talks' seamlessly 
to the back regions and vice- versa but they do this...I suspect via a 
chemical wave...some sort of resonance(?) The reason why neuron to neuron 
communications are extremely fast is because I think that the brain is a 
chemical computer using a bunch of ions to change it's own shape 
(topology). So a memory is nothing more then an intricate composition of 
hills,valleys,boulders,rocks,meandering streams etc As long as the general 
tapestry is still there (ie it's recognizable) the memory can be retrieved 
(more or less albeit not perfectly) or degraded and lost forever if it is 
beyond recognition. However what has to be kept in mind that memories could 
in fact be distributed all over the place..however it is generally accepted 
that they are localized in specific regions.So, chips in the brain, have to 
start somewhere. And then of course there are people who are trying to 
invent the elixir of life (chemical potions) to try to extend life. That 
would be great however if we are talking about a frail plus 5-10 
years...where you are still reliant on other people or machines to keep you 
alive...for the sake of being alive then I think it would not be worth it. 
Tinkering with cells,genes can get you only so far...and by all 
means..tinker away and I myself will probably benefit from such endeavors. 
However to get serious about the immortality then the brain is the only 
game in town.

comments.text:
+Justin Johnson Yeah something like that except I don't think it's possible 
to make a copy of the person (their brain/mind) in order to save them 
because that would only be a copy and not a...continuity of the self. One 
of the ways this could work is a symbiosis of neuronal tissue and 
artificial neuronal tissue. Parts of the brain that are responsible for 
simple well understood operations such as circadian rhythm, vision, 
breathing, smelling, hearing,the long axonal tracts and such can be safely 
replaced. The trick of course would be to tell all the surrounding 
supporting structures that it's sill one of "them" with the hosts' dna." If 
not then the body will obviously reject it. The more difficult part will be 
the grey/gray matter regions of the brain. And again if you opt to simply 
copy the structure (ie the positions of neurons etc) then you will only 
have a copy but NOT the potential mechanical (chemical) functions thereof. 
If the brain/synthetic tissue/mass can be grown into each other then that 
means you will start to have the ability to offload some fragments of 
experiences/memories into it. Problem here is that the thinking part is 
still done with the bio-neurons (3d spacial topological format) and that

top_comment.text:
One problem from extending human life span would be our brains. We have two 
major types of memory fluid memory, which is temporary and used short term, 
and crystallized memory, which is permanent. These memories are actually 
the same brain stuff so as we form more crystallized memory we lose fluid 
memory; this could be part of the reason why we're so good at learning at 
young ages but get worse as we age. This means that the older we are the 
more crystallized memories we have and the less fluid memory; we rely more 
on our past experiences rather than what we learn in the short term. This 
basically puts a limit on how much we can learn in our lives so if we 
extend our life to such that we learn more than that?
One interersting way to get around that could be to dump memories to 
external storage through BCI (brain computer interface) or brain scan or 
something and somehow convert previously crystallized memory back to fluid 
memory. We would also have to find someway of accessing those memories 
through BCI without them re-creating crystallized memory; but the brain 
might not do that anyway from having constant access to the information.﻿

Scientists have already created machines that can be controlled by the 
mind, as well as neuroprosthetics that offer biofeedback such as the 
sensation of touch. If we wanted to prevent an uprising, we could link the 
consciousness of every human that opted to have a neural augmentation, thus 
sharing memories, emotions & experiences as seamlessly as the words we 
speak. It would be hard to point a gun at someone if you could see their 
family, experience all their memories & the people who care about them & 
feel their emotions & pain.

On the contrary I'd say we have to evolve this way technologically, because 
the only other alternative is that we keep producing deadlier & deadlier 
weapons as we are currently doing yet no one is getting any more caring or 
any smarter; thus, by forcing an expanded consciousness through 
technological enhancement people would be able to more reasonably weigh the 
potential consequences of their actions & would be better able to innovate 
& solve problems. Sure it sounds far fetched, but I imagine if you 
explained the smart phone to someone 70 years ago, a device that can 
instantly send information across the globe & can access countless 
libraries of information, they would think you were pretty crazy too. We 
already use the smart phone like an external hippocampus; that would simply 
be taking it one step further in terms of technological integration.

captions.text:
A new discovery into how our cells work might
be able to restart our age! But you'll have

to get some cells from you as a baby... so...
that might be tough.

Hey gang, Trace here for DNews. We are all
getting older from the moment we're born.

Eventually, we'll all die. But HOW we get
there and the upper LIMIT of human life is

the subject of a study in Genome Research
published last week.

The researchers got ahold of blood from one
of the oldest known humans, Henny van Andel-Schipper.

She was the oldest person in the world when
she died in 2005 at the age of 115, wow...

that's... that's pretty old. She was born
in the 19th century and lived til the 21st.

Anyway, aging is a pretty complicated process,
but in essence scientists believe it has to
do with telomeres.

Telomeres are sort of like the tips on the
end of your shoelaces, but for chromosomes,

they maintain your genetic material and keep
it from mixing with other chromosomes. Over

time, the telomeres shorten, which causes
what's called somatic mutation. It happens
naturally over time, it's completely normal.

Apparently, Ms. Van Andel-Shipper was an organ
donor, because doctors were able to collect

tissue from her brain, blood, kidneys, arteries,
liver, lung heart, spleen, aorta, and even

a breast cancer tumor she had when she was
100! Way to go Henny!

The telomeres in her brain were similar in
length to those of a newborn, because brain

cells don't divide that often; but telomeres
in her red blood cells were 17 times shorter!

The doctors figured her blood genome had gone
through at least SIX HUNDRED mutations over
her lifetime, maybe more!

Basically, what happens is as the blood cells
are created from stem cells, new stem cells

have to come up to replace them. We're born
with about 20,000 stem cells to do this job.

Over time, the stem cells mutate -- because
telomeres -- but just like in X-Men, mutation

can be good or bad. Sometimes we get a good
cell, and other times we get cancer. We don't

ever get telepathy... at least not yet...
anyway...

So as Ms. Van Andel-Shipper aged, her stem
cells divided and divided and mutated and

divided. By the time she was old, most of
her white blood stem cells could be traced

back to TWO mother cells. This indicated most
of those 20,000 had burned out or died. She

was running on fumes for a long time... Eventually
they just... burned out.

Knowing ALL these things, why can't we give
her a refill? Obviously, we can't UNmutate

the thousands of generations of Henny's blood,
because... a copy of a copy of a copy is never

as good as the original. But what if we had
the original? What if when we're born, stem

cells are removed from our brand-new bodies
and saved to start the stem-cell telomere

shortening over; like hitting the reset button
on aging!

Maybe there's something to that "bathing in
the blood of young virgins" thing...

Anyway, lots more research is needed, but
this is the first time every somatic mutations

have been studied in such a way, and it can
teach us a lot about how the human body ages,
why, and what we can do about it.

What do you think? What would you do if you
could live for 200 years?

Tell us below because we really do read the
comments and make sure you subscribe for more

DNews every day of the week! If you' like
me are a little skeeved out by biology stories

and nature stuff you should totally check
out my friend Catie Wayne's show Weird, Gross

and Beautiful -- they wanted to call the show
Weird and Gross, but she was all like, "NO
